awd_titl_txt: Weyl Semimetals in Extreme Magnetic Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Abstract
Recent advances in the physics of material systems, often called “condensed matter” have revealed new kinds of characteristics called topological properties. Materials with certain types of topological properties can be used in manufacturing devices for quantum information technology. In this proposal, the team will investigate certain materials called Dirac and Weyl semimetals which exhibit very interesting topological properties. These materials are very challenging to synthesize, but the team has unique expertise to produce them and these will be supplied to other research groups around the world who are working to advance quantum technology. In this proposal, the materials synthesized will be studied by subjecting them to magnetic fields, to strain, and to various chemicals. Their properties will be determined through advanced techniques such as electrical transport, spectroscopy, and thermal transport measurements. The goal is to uncover new knowledge of how to tailor the topological properties of these materials so that they can be used in making devices for quantum technology. The project also includes a plan to launch an image-based book on Quantum Materials to inform the public. Graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will be recruited in this research to widen participation in this research area.

Technical Abstract
Three main projects are proposed that extend the idea of studying symmetry breaking fields beyond applied magnetic fields. Inspired by recent predictions that inhomogeneous strain can act as an effective magnetic field, the first project studies the effect of uni-axial strain fields on magneto-transport phenomena, in both magnetic and non-magnetic Weyl materials. The second project explores the question of the robustness of topological surface states when their protection by symmetry is compromised. In this case, the PI will study the question whether the mere proximity to a topologically non-trivial phase is sufficient to allow topological states. In the third project, the PI extends this idea further by studying competing interactions which can drive or suppress topological states, focusing in particular on how topological and emergent degrees of freedom transport charge and entropy in Kondo-lattice materials. These projects broaden the original conception of this research proposal, attacking one of the most interesting questions in the field - how is broken symmetry, and its associated correlations, intertwined with electronic topology? The project includes a plan to launch an image-based book on Quantum Materials, showcasing the recent technological advances that have allowed the visualization of the quantum nature of solids. Students from different backgrounds will be recruited to participate in the planned research project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project was motivated by the recent discovery of a class of materials known as "topological insulators." The understanding of these systems precipitated a much more general understanding of topological systems, including what became known as 3D Dirac semimetals, parity breaking Weyl semimetlas, magnetic Weyl semimetals and magnetic topological (axion) insulators. This proposal was focused on understanding the properties of these systems and how they can be tuned by applied magnetic fields. We focused on understading the surface states of archetypical topological insulators like Bi2Se3, Weyl systems like TaAs as well as correlated magnetic systems like CeSb and Co3Sn2S2. We focused on understanding the dynamics of these systems as well as how their underlying interactions could affect their topological properties.

One class of important discoveries is the understanding of the interplay of magnetic interactions and topological properties. We studied f-electron semimetals like CeSb and YbB12 which have strong magnetic interactions at energy scales where topological states are affected. In the former, we discovered how the local *symmetry* of the orbitals selects the topological character of the system. Specifically, the energy bands that share the same parity allows to interact, whereas if the parity is opposite the do not. This allows topological character to be preserved in the latter but *not* the former; a direct illustration of how interactions can change the topology of a system.

A number of the discoveries in this proposal have impacted how we understand the technological potential of such materials. Of these discoveries, the most influential is possibly the discovery of how magnetic topological systems can be used as spin-valves. In the system Co3Sn2S2, we discovered an unusual exchange bias that turns on with a coexisting spin texture - what we conjectured to be a background spin glass. This creates an effective way to pin the topological texture in one magnetic directions, indicated by the sign of the magentic Hall effect. In further work, we illustrated how this could be controlled by the geometry and domain wall dynamics of the system.

Other applications included understanding the optical properties of these systems like ultrafast photo-voltages, non-linear reflectivity and applications of the techniques developed here on discovering ultra-hard magnets in molecular complexes.

Broader Impacts:

The proposal can therefore be regarded as broadly impactful, facilitating the science of dozens of scientists in international collaborations. In addition, the grant served as core support for the training of young scientists, particularly young women and underrepresented minorities in science.
